PHIL 1.title: Short Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL 1.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Philosophy 5.
PHIL 1.description: An introductory course in western philosophy.

PHIL 3.title: Critical Thinking
PHIL 3.description: Practical reasoning, argumentation, and the analysis of language as instruments of sound thinking in everyday life.

PHIL 4.title: Introduction to Ethics
PHIL 4.description: An examination, at an introductory level, of such ethical issues as: why bemoral, moral relativism, the nature of virtues and vices; and possibly consideration of practical ethical problems such as abortion or war.

PHIL 7.title: Biomedical Ethics
PHIL 7.description: An examination of philosophical thinking about moral issues raised by the practice of medicine. Traditional ethical theories and problems will serve as background to, and in turn be illuminated by, such issues as informed consent, paternalism, abortion, euthanasia, and genetic engineering.

PHIL 12.title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 12.description: An introduction to several traditional philosophical problems connected with religious belief.

PHIL 100A.title: Ethics
PHIL 100A.prereq_description: One prior course in philosophy; or, Philosphy 3 (may be taken concurrently)
PHIL 100A.description: An examination of the fundamental concepts, theories, and problems of moral or political philosophy.

PHIL 100C.title: Philosophy of Language
PHIL 100C.description: Introduction to philosophical problems and theories concerning the nature of language. Topics typically include the notion of linguistic structure, theories of meaning and reference, names and descriptions, the relations between languages and thought, necessity and analytic truty, and conversational norms.

PHIL 100E.title: Metaphysics
PHIL 100E.description: Introduction to the philosophical study of the most general and fundamental features of reality. Topics vary, but may include universals, particulars, identity and individuation, substance, the nature of persons, causation, and the nature of time.

PHIL 100F.title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
PHIL 100F.prereq_description: One prior course in philosophy; or major in physics, chemistry, or
PHIL 100F.description: An introduction to the philosophical analysis of the concepts and methods of science, treating such topics as: explanation, confirmation, causation, scientific laws, the interpretation, meaning and reference of scientific theories, theory reduction and theory change, and scientific revolutions.

PHIL 107.title: Continental Philosophy
PHIL 107.description: A survey of recent continental philosophy.

PHIL 108.title: Philosophy of the Social Sciences
PHIL 108.prereq_description: One prior course from Philosophy 100B-C-D-E; or, two upper-division philosophy courses.
PHIL 108.description: Questions and problems in the methodology of the social sciences, includingwhether the social sciences have distinctive methods of explanation; modelsof rationality employed in the social sciences; and whether the social sciences can or should be value-neutral.

PHIL 112.title: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 112.description: A study of some of the following topics: religious language, the existence and nature of god, the problem of evil, religious experience, religion and morality, the rationality of religious belief.

PHIL 116.title: Meaning and Reference
PHIL 116.description: An examination of the classical theories of meaning and reference: John Stuart Mill, Gottlob Frege, Bertrand Russell, and the theory of direct reference. Investigation of solutions to the classical puzzles of meaning and reference.

PHIL 120.title: Advanced Topics in Biomedical Ethics
PHIL 120.description: Topics will include: abortion, euthanasia, medical experimentation, genetic engineering, and debts to future generations.

PHIL 121.title: Political Philosophy
PHIL 121.prereq_description: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.
PHIL 121.description: Analysis of fundamental political conceptions; the state, sovereignty, political obligation, natural rights, natural law, etc.

PHIL 122.title: Theories of Justice
PHIL 122.prereq_description: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.
PHIL 122.description: An examination, in detail, of one or more influential philosophical theories of justice.

PHIL 124A.title: Philosophy of Science
PHIL 124A.comments: May be repeated for credit up to 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 124A.description: What is science? How does it differ from non-science? Course examines both the history of science and the history of philosophy of science in an effort to discover just what science is and what it has to offer.

PHIL 124B.title: Philosophy of Physics
PHIL 124B.comments: May be repeated for credit up to 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 124B.description: Emphasizes the role that philosophical considerations played in both the evolution and actual practice of science. The major emphasis is on the creation and development of the watersheds of twentieth-century physics: relativity and quantum mechanics.

PHIL 124C.title: Philosophy of Space and Time
PHIL 124C.comments: May be repeated for credit up to 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 124C.description: Is space a thing or a series of relations holding between objects? Does time pass differently for different observers, or in different parts of the universe? Consideration of these and other questions lead to an examination of contemporary physics.

PHIL 124D.title: Philosophy of Quantum Mechanics
PHIL 124D.comments: May be repeated for credit up to 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 124D.description: Examines the history of the development of quantum mechanics, focusing on the philosophical conundrums that arose from the tortured process of finding a theory that "worked." This is done at the conceptual level, with minimal reliance on mathematical techniques.

PHIL 126.title: Social Philosophy
PHIL 126.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 126.description: This course will examine moral problems associated with economic activity; for example, economic justice and the moral basis of property rights.

PHIL 128.title: Feminist Philosophy
PHIL 128.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 128.description: In this course, we examine philosophical approaches to feminism and feminist issues. Topics covered may include inequality in the workplace and in family structures; global feminism; objectification; pornography; and prostitution.

PHIL 129.title: Philosophy of International Relations
PHIL 129.prereq_description: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.
PHIL 129.description: Study of philosophical problems in international relations.

PHIL 130.title: Freedom and Determinism
PHIL 130.prereq_description: Prerequisite: one prior course in philosophy.

PHIL 131.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 131.comments: May be repeated with consent of department provided course content is different.
PHIL 131.description: Advanced topics in applied ethics, such as the ethics of war; the ethics of procreation; and the ethics of how we treat animals.

PHIL 133.title: History of Political Thought
PHIL 133.prereq_description: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.
PHIL 133.description: A study of one or more important figures from the history of political thought.

PHIL 134.title: Moral Psychology
PHIL 134.prereq_description: Philosophy 4 or 100A; and, Philosophy 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E.
PHIL 134.description: An examination of the nature of desires, emotions, the imagination and other aspects of human psychology, and of the ways these bear on the moral evaluation of people and actions.

PHIL 135.title: Contemporary Philosophy
PHIL 135.description: Systematic investigation of topics drawn from contemporary analytic or continental philosophy.

PHIL 137.title: Aesthetic Theory
PHIL 137.description: A study of some major works in the philosophy of art from Plato to the present, with emphasis on the development and analysis of the basic concepts employed in criticism of the arts.

PHIL 138.title: Normative Ethics
PHIL 138.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 138.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 138.description: An examination of what makes actions morally right or wrong and people morally good or bad.

PHIL 139.title: Meta-Ethics
PHIL 139.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 139.description: An examination of problems concerning the meaning and justification of moral judgments.

PHIL 141.title: History of Ethics
PHIL 141.prereq_description: Philosophy 100A; or, two prior courses in philosophy.
PHIL 141.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 141.description: A study of one or more historically important moral philosophers.

PHIL 142.title: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 142.prereq_description: Philosophy 112; or two prior upper-division courses in philosophy; and, oneadditional course in philosophy.
PHIL 142.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 142.description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of religion. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 144.title: Advanced Topics in the Philosophy of Law
PHIL 144.prereq_description: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.
PHIL 144.description: Study of advanced topics in the philosophy of law.

PHIL 145.title: Punishment and Responsibility
PHIL 145.description: An examination of some of the philosophical problems of punishment and responsibility: The rationale of punishment and the legal doctrine of Mensrea; the analysis of conditions of responsibility, relations between punishment, responsibility, retribution, guilt, shame, etc.

PHIL 146.title: Philosophy in Literature
PHIL 146.description: Introduction to major problems at the intersection of philosophy and literature.  Issues addressed may include philosophical assessments of literature, authorship and interpretation, truth in fiction, significance of literary works and form for philosophy; texts include imaginative literature and philosophical essays.

PHIL 147.title: Philosophy of Economics
PHIL 147.description: An introduction to conceptual and methodological issues surrounding modern economics. Topics may include the scientific status of economics, the use of economic models, the connection between economics and moral theory, and notions of preference, choice, well-being, and rationality in economics.

PHIL 149.title: Action Theory
PHIL 149.prereq_description: One prior course from Philosophy 100B, 100C, 100D, and 100E; or, two prior course in philosophy.
PHIL 149.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 149.description: An examination of philosophical topics connected with human action, e.g. the role of intentions and desires in the explanation and justification of action and the nature of practical reason.

PHIL 150A.title: Advanced Topics in Ethical Theory
PHIL 150A.prereq_description: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.
PHIL 150A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 150A.description: Advanced topics in ethical theory. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 150B.title: Advanced Topics in Theory of Knowledge
PHIL 150B.prereq_description: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.
PHIL 150B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 150B.description: Advanced topics in theory of knowledge. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 150C.title: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHIL 150C.prereq_description: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.
PHIL 150C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 150C.description: Specific subject matter selected by the instructor. Descriptions available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 150D.title: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Mind
PHIL 150D.prereq_description: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.
PHIL 150D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 150D.description: Advanced topics in philosophy of mind. Specific subject matter is selected the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 150E.title: Advanced Topics in Metaphysics
PHIL 150E.prereq_description: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.
PHIL 150E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 150E.description: Advanced topics in metaphysics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department before each quarter.

PHIL 151.title: Pre-Socratics
PHIL 151.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.
PHIL 151.description: A study of the pre-Socratic philosophers.

PHIL 152.title: Plato
PHIL 152.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

PHIL 153.title: Aristotle
PHIL 153.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

PHIL 154.title: Socrates
PHIL 154.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.
PHIL 154.description: Socrates and his place in Greek philosophy.  The course focuses mainly on Plato's Socratic dialogues but may also treat Socrates' predecessors (principally the Sophists) and contemporary views of Socrates in other authors.

PHIL 156.title: Hellenistic Philosophy
PHIL 156.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.
PHIL 156.description: An examination of the thought of major Greek philosophers of the Hellenistic period.

PHIL 165.title: Hume
PHIL 165.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

PHIL 166A.title: Kant
PHIL 166A.prereq_description: Two prior courses from Philosophy 20B, 100B, 100D, 100E or 160.
PHIL 166A.description: An examination of the philosophy of Kant with special attention to the critique of pure reason.

PHIL 166B.title: Kant
PHIL 166B.description: An examination of the philosophy of Kant with special attention to the critique of pure reason.

PHIL 167.title: Hobbes
PHIL 167.description: This course examines the philosophy of Thomas Hobbes (1588-1679).

PHIL 173.title: Frege
PHIL 173.prereq_description: Philosophy 183 and another previous course in philosophy.
PHIL 173.description: An examination of the work of the German philosopher and logician, Gottlob Frege.

PHIL 174.title: Early Analytic Philosophy
PHIL 174.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.

PHIL 175A.title: American Philosophy
PHIL 175A.description: An examination of the roots and early development of American philosophy with special attention paid to the theory of natural rights, its role in the founding of the nation, and the movement to abolish slavery.

PHIL 175B.title: American Philosophy
PHIL 175B.description: An examination of the development of American philosophy in the 19th and early 20th century, with special attention paid to Pragmatism (e.g. the philosophical writings of Peirce, James and Dewey) and modifications of the theory of natural rights in response to the Darwinian revolution in biology.

PHIL 176.title: Historical Philosophers
PHIL 176.comments: Concurrently offered with Phil 276G. May be repeated with consent of department provided course content is different.
PHIL 176.description: Examination of historical philosophers beyond those covered in Philosophy 106 and 151-166.

PHIL 180.title: Philosophical Psychology
PHIL 180.prereq_description: One prior upper-division course in philosophy.
PHIL 180.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 180.description: An examination of some of the concepts of the mind such as those of desire,intention, action, perception, sensation, and the unconcious.

PHIL 183.title: Beginning Modern Logic
PHIL 183.description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of moder symbolic logic. Emphasis is placed on problems of translating english expressions into logical symbols and on the development of skills in using the formal proof procedures of sentential and predicate logic.

PHIL 184.title: Intermediate Modern Logic
PHIL 184.description: Further application and development of the predicate calculus, including the calculi of identity and description. An introduction to the metalogical questions of completeness, consistency, and decidability.

PHIL 185.title: Advanced Modern Logic
PHIL 185.description: Topics from the theory of formal systems, set theory, recursive function theory, and automata theory.

PHIL 186.title: Philosophical Logic
PHIL 186.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
PHIL 186.description: Topics in logical theory and the philosophy of logic: intensional logic andother non-standard logics (such as modal logic); discussion of results of modern logic and their philosophical implications.

PHIL 187.title: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL 187.description: Logistic, formalist, and intuitionist views of th nature of mathematics. Epistemological problems of applied mathematics.

PHIL 188.title: Theory of Value
PHIL 188.description: Study of theories of the nature and structure of the good and of value judgments generally.

PHIL 192.title: Internship in Philosophy
PHIL 192.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in philosophy; consent of department and instructor
PHIL 192.comments: Students must have a 3.0 overall grade-point average. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units but only 4 units may count toward major.
PHIL 192.description: Practical experience and application of analytical skills learned in philosophy as interns with agencies and business. Periodic and final reports required under faculty direction.

PHIL 197A.title: Senior Honors Thesis
PHIL 197A.prereq_description: Enrollment limited to senior honors philosophy majors; by consent of instructor and departmental approval.
PHIL 197A.description: A continuous two-quarter research and writing tutorial designed for senior honors majors. The first term will be spent mainly in selecting and researching a topic for the thesis.

PHIL 197B.title: Senior Honors Thesis
PHIL 197B.prereq_description: Enrollment limited to senior honors philosophy majors; by consent of instructor and departmental approval.
PHIL 197B.description: A continuous two-quarter research and writing tutorial designed for senior honors majors. The second term will be spent mainly in the writing of the thesis.

PHIL 197P.title: Senior Project for Majors with Ethics and Public Policy Emphasis
PHIL 197P.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in philosophy; consent of department.
PHIL 197P.comments: May be repeated for credit to 8 units with consent of instructor.
PHIL 197P.description: A research and writing tutorial on some topic relevant to issues in ethics and public policy. A written proposal of the project must be approved by the undergraduate adviser and the instructor.

PHIL 199.title: Independent Studies in Philosophy
PHIL 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in
PHIL 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters. Philosophy 199 may be repeated to a maximum of 12 units. No more than 12 units may be applied to the major. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
PHIL 199.description: A written statement of the proposed program of study must be presented to the instructor for his or her approval before the student signs up for the course.

PHIL 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistant
PHIL 199RA.comments: Students must enroll under instructor number and have a minimum 3.0 GPA forthe preceding 3 quarters. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ course combined. Philosophy 199RA may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 5 units.
PHIL 199RA.description: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research.

PHIL 208G.title: Philosophy of the Social Sciences
PHIL 208G.description: Questions and problems in the methodology of the social sciences, includingwhether the social sciences have distinctive methods of explanation; modelsof rationality employed in the social sciences and whether the social sciences can or should be value-neutral.

PHIL 212G.title: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 212G.description: Study at the graduate level of topics in the philosophy of religion.

PHIL 216G.title: Meaning and Reference
PHIL 216G.description: An examination of the classical theories of meaning and reference: John Stuart Mill, Gottlob Frege, Bertrand Russell, and the theory of direct reference. Solutions to the classical puzzles of meaning and reference are investigated.

PHIL 220G.title: Topics in Bio-medical Ethics
PHIL 220G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected topics in bio-medical ethics; topics will include (but not be limited to ) abortion, euthanasia, medical experimentation, genetic engineering, and debts to future generations.

PHIL 221G.title: Political Philosophy
PHIL 221G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected problems in political philosophy.

PHIL 222G.title: Theories of Justice
PHIL 222G.description: A study at the graduate level of an examination, in detail, of one or more influential philosophical theories of justice.

PHIL 224A.title: Philosophy of Science
PHIL 224A.description: What is science? How does it differ from non-science? Course examines both the history of science and the history of philosophy of science in an effort to discover just what science is and what it has to offer.

PHIL 224B.title: Philosophy of Physics
PHIL 224B.description: Emphasizes the role that philosophical considerations played in both the evolution and actual practice of science. The major emphasis is on the creation and development of the watersheds of twentieth-century physics: relativity and quantum mechanics.

PHIL 224C.title: Philosophy of Space and Time
PHIL 224C.description: Is space a thing or a series of relations holding between objects? Does time pass differently for different observers, or in different parts of the universe? Consideration of these, and other questions leads to an examination of contemporary physics.

PHIL 224D.title: Philosophy of Quantum Mechanics
PHIL 224D.description: Examines the history of the development of quantum mechanics, focusing on the philosophical conundrums that arose from the tortured process of finding a theory that "worked." This is done at the conceptual level, with minimal reliance on mathematical techniques.

PHIL 224G.title: Philosophy of Science
PHIL 224G.description: A study at the graduate level of problems in the philosophy of science.

PHIL 226G.title: Social Philosophy
PHIL 226G.description: A study at the graduate level of moral problems associated with economic activity, for example, economic justice and the moral basis of property rights.

PHIL 228G.title: Feminist Philosophy
PHIL 228G.description: A study at the graduate level of philosophical approaches to feminism and feminist issues. Topics covered may include inequality in the workplace and in family structures; global feminism; objectification; pornography; and prostitution.

PHIL 230G.title: Freedom and Determinism
PHIL 230G.description: A study at the graduate level of the problem of whether human action is free or determined.

PHIL 233G.title: History of Political Thought
PHIL 233G.description: A study of one or more important figues from the history of political thought.

PHIL 234G.title: Moral Psychology
PHIL 234G.description: An examination of the nature of desires, emotions, the imagination, and other aspects of human psychology, and of the ways these bear on the moral evaluation of people and actions.

PHIL 235G.title: Contemporary Philosophy
PHIL 235G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected topics in contemporary philosophy.

PHIL 236G.title: Aesthetics
PHIL 236G.description: Topics may include the aesthetic experience, the aesthetic object, the creative act, and art criticism.

PHIL 237G.title: Aesthetic Theory
PHIL 237G.description: A study at the graduate level of the development and analysis of the basic concepts employed in criticism of the arts.

PHIL 238G.title: Normative Ethics
PHIL 238G.description: An examination of what makes actions morally right or wrong and people morally good or bad.

PHIL 239G.title: Meta-ethics
PHIL 239G.description: An examination of problems concerning the meaning and justification of moral judgments.

PHIL 241G.title: History of Ethics
PHIL 241G.description: A study of one or more historically important moral philosophers.

PHIL 242G.title: Topics in the Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 242G.description: A study at the graduate level of topic in the philosophy of religion.

PHIL 244G.title: Advanced Topics in the Philosophy of Law
PHIL 244G.description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of law.

PHIL 245G.title: Punishment and Responsibility
PHIL 245G.description: An examination of some of the philosophical problems of punishment and responsibility: the rationale of punishment and the legal doctrine of mens rea; the analysis of conditions of responsibility, relations between punishment, responsibility, retribution, guilt, shame, etc.

PHIL 247.title: Philosophy of Economics
PHIL 247.description: An introduction at the graduate level to conceptual and methodological issues surrounding modern economics. Topics may include the scientific status of economics, the use of economic models, the connection between economics and moral theory, and notions of preference, choice, well-being, and rationality in economics.

PHIL 249G.title: Action Theory
PHIL 249G.description: An examination of philosophical topics connected with human action, e.g. the role of intentions and desires in the explanation and justification of action and the nature of practical reasons.

PHIL 250A.title: Topics in Ethical Theory
PHIL 250A.description: A study at the graduate level of topics in ethical theory.

PHIL 250B.title: Topics in Theory of Knowledge
PHIL 250B.description: A study at the graduate level of topics in th theory of knowledge.

PHIL 250C.title: Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHIL 250C.description: A study at the graduate level of topics in the philosophy of language.

PHIL 250D.title: Topics in Philosophy of Mind
PHIL 250D.description: A study at the graduate level of topics in the philosophy of mind.

PHIL 250E.title: Topics in Metaphysics
PHIL 250E.description: A study at the graduate level of topics in metaphysics.

PHIL 251G.title: Pre-Socratics
PHIL 251G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of the pre-Socratic era.

PHIL 252G.title: Plato
PHIL 252G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Plato.

PHIL 253G.title: Aristotle
PHIL 253G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Aristotle.

PHIL 254G.title: Socrates
PHIL 254G.description: A study at the graduate level of Socrates and his place in Greek philosophy.  The course focuses mainly on Plato's Socratic dialogues but may also treat Socrates' predecessors (principally the Sophists) and contemporary views of Socrates in other authors.

PHIL 256G.title: Hellenistic Philosophy
PHIL 256G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of the Hellenistic philosophers.

PHIL 261G.title: Spinoza
PHIL 261G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Spinoza.

PHIL 262G.title: Leibniz
PHIL 262G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Leibniz.

PHIL 264G.title: Berkeley
PHIL 264G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Berkeley.

PHIL 265G.title: Hume
PHIL 265G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Hume.

PHIL 266A.title: Kant
PHIL 266A.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Kant.

PHIL 266B.title: Kant
PHIL 266B.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Kant.

PHIL 267G.title: Hobbes
PHIL 267G.description: This course examines the philosophy of Thomas Hobbes (1588-1679).

PHIL 268G.title: Nietzsche
PHIL 268G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Nietzsche.

PHIL 272G.title: Heidegger
PHIL 272G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Heidegger.

PHIL 273G.title: Frege
PHIL 273G.description: An examination of the work of the german philosopher and logician, Gottlob Frege.

PHIL 275A.title: American Philosophy A
PHIL 275A.description: An examination of the roots and early development of American philosophy with special attention paid to the theory of natural rights, its role in the founding of the nation, and the movement to abolish slavery.

PHIL 275B.title: American Philosophy B
PHIL 275B.description: An examination of the development of American philosophy in the 19th and early 20th century, with special attention paid to Pragmatism (e.g. the philosophical writings of Peirce, James and Dewey) and modifications of the theory of natural rights in response to the Darwinian revolution in biology.

PHIL 276G.title: Historical Philosophers
PHIL 276G.comments: Concurrently offered with Phil 176. May be repeated with consent of department provided course content is different.
PHIL 276G.description: Examination of historical philosophers beyond those covered in Philosophy 106 and 151-166.

PHIL 283G.title: Beginning Symbolic Logic
PHIL 283G.description: An introduction to symbolic logic at the graduate level.

PHIL 284G.title: Intermediate Symbolic Logic
PHIL 284G.description: A continuation of the study of symbolic logic.

PHIL 285G.title: Advanced Symbolic Logic
PHIL 285G.description: An advanced study of symbolic logic.

PHIL 286G.title: Philosophical Logic
PHIL 286G.description: Topics in logical theory and the philosophy of logic: intensional logic andother non-standard logics (such as modal logic); discussion of results of modern logic and their philosophical implications.

PHIL 287G.title: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL 287G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected problem in the philosophy of mathematics.

PHIL 288G.title: Theory of Value
PHIL 288G.description: A study at the graduate level of selected problems in the theory of value.

PHIL 296A.title: Seminar in Ethics
PHIL 296A.description: Graduate seminar in ethics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 296B.title: Seminar in Epistemology
PHIL 296B.description: Graduate seminar in epistemology. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 296C.title: Seminar in the Philosophy of Language
PHIL 296C.description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of language. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 296D.title: Seminar in the Philosophy of Mind
PHIL 296D.description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of mind. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 296E.title: Seminar in Metaphysics
PHIL 296E.description: Graduate seminar in metaphysics. Specific subject matter is selected by theinstructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 297A.title: Seminar in the History of Philosophy
PHIL 297A.description: Graduate seminar in the history of philosophy. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 297B.title: Seminar on Contemporary Figures in Philosophy
PHIL 297B.description: Graduate seminar on contemporary figures in philosophy. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 298A.title: Seminar in Aesthetics
PHIL 298A.description: Graduate seminar in aesthetics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 298B.title: Seminar on Problems in Legal and Political Philosophy
PHIL 298B.description: Graduate seminar on problems in legal and political philosophy. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 299A.title: Seminar in the Philosophy of Logic
PHIL 299A.description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of logic. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 299B.title: Seminar in the Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL 299B.description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of mathematics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 299C.title: Seminar in the Philosophy of Science
PHIL 299C.description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of science. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

PHIL 500.title: Apprentice Teaching in Philosophy
PHIL 500.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
PHIL 500.description: A teaching practicum involving the study and development of effective teaching techniques in philosophy. Each student will be responsible for andteach a class section in an undergraduate course in philosophy. One meetingper week with instructor and one or more discussion section meetings, and attendance in the lecture of the assigned course are required.

PHIL 501.title: Teaching Assistant Training
PHIL 501.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
PHIL 501.description: Instructional training. Orientation in professional conduct and responsibilities; observation of student's teaching (in the form of facultyvisits or videotaping) and follow-up conferences; discussion of teaching evaluations and workshops on pedagogical problems.

PHIL 594.title: First-Year Proseminar
PHIL 594.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
PHIL 594.description: Special seminar for first-year graduate students in Philosophy.

PHIL 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
PHIL 596.prereq_description: Graduate student in philosophy; Consent of instructor.
PHIL 596.description: A written proposal must be approved by the instructor and department chair.

PHIL 597.title: Individual Study for Master's and/or Ph.D. Examinations for Advancement to Candidacy
PHIL 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
PHIL 597.description: Individual preparation for the doctoral qualifying examination.

PHIL 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
PHIL 598.description: This course is for research and writing of the master's thesis.
